EDITORIALS
TO FRESHMEN

T N the opening issue of a college periodical it is customary to extend
a welcome and to offer certain amount of advice to the entering
class. We do the former with pleasure as we note that each year the
number of students grows larger.
As to giving advice, this seems rather futile. Each student has
an experienced official 'University advisor to aid him in arranging his
schedule. Furthermore, he has innumerable unofficial advisors. For
some unaccountable reason, the majority of upperclassmen feel it is
their duty to map out the schedules of the Freshmen. They fail to
consider the fact that the preparation that the Freshman has received
previous to entering Hopkins may be entirely different from theirs, and
that his natural abilities probably extend along entirely different lines.
A course which may have been both easy and beneficial to one man
may be quite difficult and useless to another. The best advice to the
first year man is that he accept no advice from upperclassmen as to
which courses he should pursue.
The majority of Freshmen will find that they will have a considerable amount of spare time even after thoroughly preparing their
work. We would like to make a few suggestions as to how this time
be spent. Previous to this year fraternities made it their business to
see that all pledges participated in some activity. This semester no first
year man will be unduly persuaded to try out for an athletic team or
a non-athletic activity.
Freshman will, however, find it to their advantage to participate
in activities. They themselves can best decide what form of activity
will be most beneficial to them. Practically all upperclassmen will be
found to be prejudiced. The best advice that we can give is to stick
at whatever activity is selected. Do not become discouraged.
It is our belief that the more a man does the more he can do.
If he finds his studies easy, he will begin to loaf. This is an art that
can be easily mastered and the more it is attempted the more it will
be practiced. If he maintains a full schedule till night, he will find
that his work will be more easily completed. We sincrely hope that
the various activities on the campus will be raised to a higher level
through the efforts of the class of 1934.

LIBRARY IMPROVEMENTS
To the Editor of the News-Letter:
Students returning to the University from their summer vacations will notice changes in the main
reading room in Gilman Hall. The
improvements in that room, begun
by the installation of the King Memorial Windows,are now complete;
and members of the University
whose work does not ordinarily
bring them into Gilman Hall are
cordially invited to come and see
what has been done.
The new furnishings of the bay
are the gift of an alumnus, a good
friend and classmate of the Librarian, Mr. W. L. Ross, of New
York City, who generously provided the means of making the furniture fit the beautiful windows. It
is the purpose of his gift to make
that part of the room so attractive
that both students and faculty will
be tempted to linger in it for casual
reading not required by study or research.
To heighten the temptation it is
proposed to have a few good books
on the tables, gathered into what
is to be known as a Leisure Reading Collection. The books will
necessarily be few, since they are
to be secured by other means than
by purchase with the regular book
fund o fthe Library. The Librarian hereby confesses his willingness to accept contributions of
money for the purchase of additions
to the collection. The most important point, however, is this—that
these books should not be taken
away from the bay and the tables
should not be used for studying
text books and writing themes, but
should be reserved for the casual
reader. It is the hope of the Library staff that students will help
to establish this practice as a tradition.
New students, who see the King
Windows for the first time, may
secure a sheet of description of the
printers' marks used in the decorations by applying at the desk. They
are quite welcome to bring their
friends to see the room. It has been
said by some of our visitors to be
one of the most attractive college
reading rooms in the country, and
we are glad to have friends of the
University inspect it.

the office. A new bulletin board,

particulars, has been erected.

EDITORIALS
TO FRESHMEN

T N the opening issue of a college periodical it is customary to extend
a welcome and to offer certain amount of advice to the entering
class. We do the former with pleasure as we note that each year the
number of students grows larger.
As to giving advice, this seems rather futile. Each student has
an experienced official 'University advisor to aid him in arranging his
schedule. Furthermore, he has innumerable unofficial advisors. For
some unaccountable reason, the majority of upperclassmen feel it is
their duty to map out the schedules of the Freshmen. They fail to
consider the fact that the preparation that the Freshman has received
previous to entering Hopkins may be entirely different from theirs, and
that his natural abilities probably extend along entirely different lines.
A course which may have been both easy and beneficial to one man
may be quite difficult and useless to another. The best advice to the
first year man is that he accept no advice from upperclassmen as to
which courses he should pursue.
The majority of Freshmen will find that they will have a considerable amount of spare time even after thoroughly preparing their
work. We would like to make a few suggestions as to how this time
be spent. Previous to this year fraternities made it their business to
see that all pledges participated in some activity. This semester no first
year man will be unduly persuaded to try out for an athletic team or
a non-athletic activity.
Freshman will, however, find it to their advantage to participate
in activities. They themselves can best decide what form of activity
will be most beneficial to them. Practically all upperclassmen will be
found to be prejudiced. The best advice that we can give is to stick
at whatever activity is selected. Do not become discouraged.
It is our belief that the more a man does the more he can do.
If he finds his studies easy, he will begin to loaf. This is an art that
can be easily mastered and the more it is attempted the more it will
be practiced. If he maintains a full schedule till night, he will find
that his work will be more easily completed. We sincrely hope that
the various activities on the campus will be raised to a higher level
through the efforts of the class of 1934.

away from the bay and the tables
should not be used for studying
text books and writing themes, but

reader. It is the hope of the Library staff that students will help

secure a sheet of description of the
printers' marks used in the decorations by applying at the desk. They
are quite welcome to bring their
friends to see the room. It has been
said by some of our visitors to be
one of the most attractive college
reading rooms in the country, and
we are glad to have friends of the
University inspect it.

CHANGES POLICY At the first Assembly yesterday,
First Issue Dedicated to Freshmen
According to reports emanating
from the Black and Blue Jay office, that magazine will once again
undergo a change in the editorial
policy. It is proposed that the
forthcoming number will discontinue the literary policy followed
more or less successfully during
the last two years. The intended
change will have as its aim the publication of a magazine that is purely
humorous. This is a revision of
the type of magazine that was edited
before Ben Kolb inaugurated his
idea of a periodical; that is, a combination of humor and literature.
The keynote will be a ton of humor
and an ounce of seriousness.
Among other changes, "Seen
from the Pit," which has been a
part of the magazine, has been deleted and will be replaced by
"Around the Campus," which has
been expanded to two pages.
The cover will also be changed.
Formerly the design was one by
Ben Kolb, editor o fthe Jay in 1929;
this year, however, a •new idea—
more in the spirit of the first issue—
A Freshman number—will be used.
There are going to be several
articles by noted writers. Several
of the prominent members of the
faculty have consented to write features for the magazine.
Not only has the policy of the
magazine been changed, but even
the office. A new bulletin board,
which will inform the staff of all
particulars, has been erected.
It is expected by Harold Bloom,
the editor-in-chief, and Wilson
Rutherford, the business manager
that the Blue Jay will be bigger and
better than ever.
Competition for offices on the
business and editorial staff will begin on Friday. All candidates are
asked to report at 12.30. There
are many open positions and an excellent chance for aspiring writers
to display their talent.
—Last year the Blue Jay rated third
among college magazines of the
country.
